trial_identification.studytitle: The influence of oral taste sensitivity on satiety and nutrients intake in human subjects
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Influence of oral taste sensitivity on satiety and nutrient intake after different soup preloads:A randomized, crossover study in adult human subjects

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Normal oral and gastrointestinal development and function

interventions.comparator: cross-over intervention. All participants will consume all three types of soups.. The sweet soup, the MSG soup and the control soup.

primaryOutcome.outcome: sensory specific satiety to sweet soup/MSG soup; subjects will rate the pleasantness on visual analogue scale with very unpleasant and very pleasant at the two ends, after tasting a small sample of the sweet soup and the MSG soup, both before and at two time points (0min and 60min) after soup consumption, sensory specific satiety score will be calculated with the subjective ratings;
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Before soup preload and at both 0 minute and at 60 minutes after soup preload consumption

primaryOutcome.outcome: Macronutrients and energy intake, All food items will be weighed before and after consumption to calculate the quantity of each food item consumed, the macronutrients and energy consumption will be further calculated based on the nutritional value provided by manufacturer with the amount (gram) of food consumed.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Directly after the ad libitum Buffet food eating at each of the 3 testing sessions

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Appetite/satiety sensations (hunger/fullness) using a labeled magnitude satiety scale (LMSS);
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At arrival, 0, 15, 30, 60 minutes after soup preload and after ad libitum meal

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Appetite/satiety sensation (subjective desire to eat) using a visual analogue scale (VAS);
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At arrival, 0, 15, 30, 60 minutes after soup preload and after ad libitum meal

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Appetite/satiety sensation (subjective ratings on how much food they think they can eat, also known as perspective food consumption) on a visual analogue scale (VAS);
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At arrival, 0, 15, 30, 60 minutes after soup preload and after ad libitum meal

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Hormone in saliva: ghrelin, GLP-1 and leptin will be measured using ELISA
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At arrival, 0, 30, 60 minutes after soup preload and after ad libitum meal

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Healthy, non-vegetarian. Everyone who shows interest in participating the study, judge themselves as healthy and do not meet the exclusion criteria.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: smoking vegetarian difficulties with eating or swallowing taste/olfactory dysfunction

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The aim of this project is to study whether the oral sensitivity to basic tastes (umami taste, Monosodium glutamate MSG and sweet taste; sucrose) would influence on human eating behavior which include total energy intake, sensitivity to satiety, appetite hormone profiles and salivary flow rate and hormone profiles. The purpose of this project is to improve the understanding of the correlation between taste perception and food eating behaviors.
